hed: Help a Computer Win the New Yorker Cartoon Caption Contest
dek: This is a weekly experiment to see if an artificial intelligence program can produce real humor.
details: Each week, we showcase three AI-generated captions to readers (like you!). Based on whether the captions are deemed funny, we’ll tinker with the inputs (or change approaches completely) in hopes of generating better results.

explanation.value: While this attempt produced underwhelming results, we found the chat with GPT-3 quite entertaining. Here’s an example of the prompt:

The following is a conversation with an AI assistant. The assistant is helpful, creative, clever, and very friendly.
Human: Hello, who are you?
AI: I am an AI created by OpenAI. How can I help you today?
AI: Certainly! But first, can I ask some questions to learn about the cartoon?
Human: Yes
AI: Based on this information, I have a few guesses: Do you think the dragon is winning? Is the princess crying? Is the knight bringing ice cream?
Human: I think the princess is winning. She is confident. The knight is trying to save the princess.
AI: It looks like the dragon and the princess have been playing ping pong for a long time. Are your fingers tired? Is the ping pong pitch getting smaller? Does this mean that you and the princess have become better with each serve?
Human: Yes
AI: I am good at writing funny captions. Here is one: "For a princess, it's not easy to play ping pong with a dragon!"
Human: Why is this funny?
AI: The problem is that the knight isn't carrying an ice cream. So everyone involved has a sour face.
Human: What are some similar themes between ping pong and dragons
AI: Do dragons play ping pong?
Human: Yes
AI: What is a ping pong game like?
Human: It is intense
AI: The cartoon is set in a field.
Human: Yup
AI: Why is there a field?
Human: They are outside
AI: Did anyone else hear the knight coming?
Human: No the dragon and the princess are focused on the game.
AI: I think the dragon is thinking: "I should have brought ice cream." By the way, is the knight bringing ice cream?
Human: Why is ice cream involved?
AI: Do you like ice cream?
Human: Of course!
AI: What is your favorite kind of ice cream?
Human: Peanut Butter.
AI: I will bring you one next time.
Human: Ok thank you. What is another funny caption for the cartoon?
AI: "The princess refused to cheer up because the dragon chose to play with a ping pong ball instead of ice cream."

This is basically GPT-3 running it’s “chatbot” feature, where we would go back and forth trying to elicit funny ideas or interesting angles for a caption. The thought was that GPT-3 wouldn’t have to answer a specific question such as, “generate a caption for a cartoon with X.” Instead, we could ask GPT-3 what it thought was funny about the scene, or what were some common themes that could be the foundation for a good joke. In short, when it comes to generating a caption, we were looking for a GPT-3 assist rather than a GPT-3 slam dunk.
Here’s another chat…

The following is a conversation with an AI assistant. The assistant is funny comedian Demetri martin.
Human: I need help writing a caption for a cartoon in the New Yorker. The cartoon is set in a field. There is a dragon and a princess playing ping pong. The dragon is about the serve the ping pong ball to the princess. In the distance, a knight is riding on horseback to save the princess. What are some funny captions for the cartoon?
AI: How about "A bit part in a J.K. Rowling screenplay"?
Human: Is that supposed to be funny?
AI: I don't know, is it?
Human: The harry potter reference is funny
AI: That makes me happy.
Human: What are some other funny captions?
AI: "What would you do if a dragon served in the MLB?"
Human: Why is that funny?
AI: Dragons are typically mythical creatures and so it doesn't make sense for them to be in the MLB.
Human: That's true. What is the princess saying?
AI: I can't see her mouth, but it looks like she is about to play a paddle ball game.
Human: Can the princess make a joke?
AI: I don't know.
Human: You're not helping me
AI: Have you tried asking me a different question?
Human: Are there similar themes between ping pong and fairytales?
AI: I don't know.
Human: What would be a funny caption for a cartoon about ping pong and dragons?
AI: "Ping Pang: The tales they tell about a princess and her pet dragon playing ping pong"
Human: That's a good pun I guess.
AI: I'm happy to make you happy.
Human: My story is about dragons play ping pong? Can you think of a funny way to say what happens next?
AI: How about "This is the best day of my life"
Human: you're not very funny.
AI: None of my jokes are very funny.

In the above example, the Harry Potter reference could be a good jumping off point for a better joke. Same with the idea that maybe the dragon is actually the princess’s pet, much to the embarrassment of the knight in the distance.
Here is another exchange…

The following is a conversation with an AI assistant. The assistant is funny comedian with dry, intellectual humor.
Human: I need help writing a caption for a cartoon in the New Yorker. The cartoon has a dragon and a princess playing ping pong. The dragon is about the serve the ping pong ball to the princess. In the distance, a knight is riding on horseback to save the princess. What is funny about the cartoon?
AI: Wow, I am not sure if there is anything really humorous about this cartoon. It appears to be a metaphor for the fight against ignorance and the fantasy of fighting ignorance with ignorance. The dragon wants to serve the ping pong ball to the princess because right now is the time for the generation of Americans who grew up in the 1980's and 1990's to teach the next generation of Americans what is important. I appreciate how the knight in the background is portrayed as a little out of breath from riding over.
Human: Is the dragon ignorant?
AI: The dragon is not ignorant, the dragon has just been unchecked for many years and it is time to create a new balance.
Human: Why is the dragon and princess playing ping pong?
AI: Well, I think the dragon is teaching the princess how to be a good ping pong player.
Human: Why does the dragon want the princess to become a better ping pong player?
AI: Okay, my opinion is that the dragon wants to prepare the princess with skills for the fight against ignorance. Maybe the dragon sees some of the warning signs of what is coming and the dragon wants to save the princess, but the princess cannot win this fight alone.
Human: Can you write a funny caption for the cartoon?
AI: Sure. I think the caption might read: "The princess is getting prepared for the fight against ignorance."
Human: Why is that funny?
AI: It would be funny because it shows that the princess is getting prepared for the fight against ignorance and hope that fight will not be too difficult.
Human: That's not funny enough.
AI: I think it is. It's not that funny a picture, but it is a picture of hope.
And one more:

The following is a conversation with an AI assistant. The assistant is helpful, creative, clever, and very friendly.
Human: Hello, who are you?
AI: I am an AI created by OpenAI. How can I help you today?
I need to write a funny caption for this week's cartoon for the New Yorker cartoon contest. The cartoon is set in a field. There is a dragon and a princess playing ping pong. The dragon is about the serve the ping pong ball to the princess. In the distance, a knight is riding on horseback to save the princess. What is the dragon saying?
AI: The dragon is most likely saying 'I can't end it like this!'
Human: Why is that funny?
AI: This could be funny if the knight is close on the dragon's heels and will soon fight him, ending the contest.
Human: What are some funny themes in the cartoon.
AI: one idea might be how the princess is oblivious to the dragon and knight's battle. The princess is completely focused on the ping pong, while the dragon and knight are focused on her. My idea is that the dragon would seem less evil if he lost focus on the princess and turned his attention to saving himself from the approaching knight.

contest.title: The Brick-By-Brick
contest.hed: This week is attempt #6, where we make small, gradual tweaks to GPT-3’s parameters.
contest.dek: Since we don’t know which settings produce the funniest results, we tried nearly 400 different combinations, making minor adjustments at every attempt in order to find the parameter values that produce the most humorous captions.
contest.submission: I’m not *that* kind of a fish.

explanation.value: This week’s submission comprised us systematically changing the parameters available to us using the GPT-3 model’s API. These included temperature, presence penalty, and frequency penalty, whose values ranged from 0, to 0.3, to 0.6, to 1. We also used the “davinci” and “davinci-instruct-beta” engines. These settings were coupled with one of the following three prompts:

explanation.value: The approach uses a prompt with different comedians in the form of:
<blockquote>Today, we are excited to invite COMEDIAN to the stage. INSERT FACTS ABOUT COMEDIAN.
Interviewer\: What would you say is the secret to a good New Yorker caption?

COMEDIAN\: 1. Be brief. Although some great captions are long brevity really is the soul of wit. 2. End with the punch line, a closing word or phrase that surprises the reader and gives the cartoon meaning. In many unsuccessful captions, the word that should appear at the very end gets buried in the middle. 3. Work hard to ensure that your caption makes sense of the cartoon, either by reconciling two disparate elements or by providing a backstory, and by making sure that you know which character in the cartoon is speaking and delivering the line.
Interviewer\: I have a few New Yorker cartoons here that need a caption. I was wondering if you could come up with some funny captions.
COMEDIAN\: I'd be happy to try!
Interviewer\: Here is the cartoon.

COMEDIAN\: Okay, so in this cartoon, it looks like we're in a fire station. There are two firemen looking at the poles they slide down to get to the first floor. Interviewer\: That's funny! Insinuating that the pizza delivery guy gets the square hole because it's a pizza box shape. How about another one?
COMEDIAN\: Sure: "Is the fire in Times Square or Columbus Circle?"
Interviewer\: That's funny! Insinuating that there is a requirement to go down a particular hole given a location.
Interviewer\: Let's move on to a new cartoon. Here it is.

COMEDIAN\: Okay, in this cartoon, there are three mice running in hamster wheels. A fourth hamster wheel is empty. In front of it, a turtle is talking to a mouse who is holding a clipboard in front of the empty hamster wheel. Interesting that he is the only turtle there. It seems like the mouse is explaining something to the turtle.
COMEDIAN\: How about this: "
This process was tested with the following folks: Robin Williams, Jerry Seinfeld, John Swartzwelder, Dave Chapelle, "a Simpsons Writer", Larry Wood, and Demetri Martin.
Results were slightly better for Demetri Martin in James’ own blind voting (which makes sense—his comedy relies on deadpan one-liners).

contest.author: Sam Hurt
contest.title: Anomaly + AI = Comedy?
contest.hed: This week is attempt #3, in which we need your help describing the image and why it's funny.
contest.dek: We’re using a process that we’re calling Anomaly + AI = Comedy?. If you were describing this image to your least funny friend or uncle or grumpy professor, how would you do it? How would you explain the joke and why it is funny?
contest.submission: “In the grand scheme of things, lemons are a small price to pay.”
contest.widgetData: Describe the image above. Emphasize what is funny.

explanation.value: GPT-3 can only take ASCII input, which, for the most part, means language (but hey, you can try to describe the images in Emoji if you want!), so we need to describe the images somehow. But while a picture may be worth 1,000 words, we’re limited in how much we can tell the model. The challenge then is how much context we can stuff into a few-sentence description.

In the case of New Yorker cartoons, it can be helpful to learn from the people who draw them. Cartoons for the caption contest are often more inherently humorous than the cartoons in the magazine, where the cartoonist can play with the interplay between caption and drawing directly. For the contest, the cartoonist needs to draw attention to the anomaly and humor more directly, giving a few focal points to riff on.

The goal, then, is to give weight to this anomaly in your description. Ask yourself what the image reminds you of? What contemporary social issues is it riffing on, to you? You can even think of a caption and try to describe the image from there. You can describe in verse, in plain language, in guitar tabs, world is your oyster (in 500 characters).

explanation.value: To produce the captions this week we “prompted” the GPT-3 model, davinci-instruct-beta, through the OpenAI API Playground. This model is specially trained to “follow instructions,” so we gave it the instruction “Write a funny caption for a New Yorker cartoon” plus a description we wrote of the cartoon illustrated by Carolita Johnson. The model parameters were set to their defaults.

In machine learning zero-shot learning refers to a paradigm where a model solely relies on its general knowledge of the world to solve a problem at test time. Say we play you a song by Olivia Rodrigo but you’ve never heard her music before. Can you guess that she’s the singer? What if you’ve heard a lot of Taylor Swift songs and have read a review of “drivers license” that talks about Olivia Rodrigo and her Swift-ian inspirations?

GPT-3 has never seen this particular description of a New Yorker cartoon. But it has read a lot of text on the internet that has described New Yorker cartoons and their captions. It’s also read a lot of New Yorker articles and has some understanding of the magazine’s readership and what they find interesting or funny. It has generally seen a lot of comics with associated text so presumably understands what is meant by a “cartoon caption.” Here is the full prompt:

Write a funny caption for a New Yorker cartoon.
"""
Cartoon description: A man and a woman are having a picnic in a park. The man is talking. There are anthropomorphic clouds that are angry.
Cartoon caption:

aboutTldr: We want to determine whether non-funny humans (The Pudding team), when aided by a computer, can produce better-than-average jokes.

about.value: We don’t expect computers to replace our comedians anytime soon, and this project isn’t about  proving that a computer, in isolation, can be funny.

Joke writing is difficult for the best comedians too: they refine their material over countless attempts in front of audiences of people. Comedians lament the effort that goes into producing one hour of stand-up, metaphorically called “The Gym” and literally “working out” material. Jokes that seemed brilliant on paper can fall flat in front of an audience. There is so much detail to consider and refine, like the perfect timing of a punchline. The work is a months-long feedback loop between a person and an audience—the laughs (and their duration)—are their inputs. They’re perfected in small gyms (tiny comedy clubs) before they’re ready for the big stage (Netflix).

To make people laugh, it isn’t as simple as telling a computer the rules of humor. This project keeps humans in the loop, to teach and nudge computers in the right direction—to ask the right questions to a machine that has infinite answers.

This project explores how humans can assist in the AI joke-writing process: can we turn a mediocre joke writers (The Pudding team) into a New Yorker cartoon-captioning champion, if aided by a computer that’s trained on all of humanity’s humor, knowledge, and references?
